title: Post-Election Emergency Strategy Meeting - Multi-Party Conference
location: Hybrid - Swanage Community Center and Zoom
participants: Sandra Williams (via phone from County Hall)
content:
BARRY CADE: Good morning everyone. Thank you all for joining this emergency session. Following Phil's successful election to the council yesterday, we need to coordinate our next moves quickly. The DCF and Hollister won't take this lying down.

PHILIPPE EDES: Thanks Barry. Can everyone hear Sandra on the phone?

SANDRA WILLIAMS: [Phone audio] Yes, I'm here. Congratulations Phil! Things are moving fast at County. The Statistics Authority accepted your complaint - the investigation starts Monday.

MARGARET THORNE: That's excellent news. I've been in touch with three other councillors who are ready to support a motion to suspend the Shore Rd closure pending investigation.

UNKNOWN SPEAKER 1: Sorry to interrupt, I'm Detective Inspector Rachel Kumar from Dorset Police. I'm here because we've received complaints about harassment during the campaign. Mr. Harrison from the News filed a report.

MICHAEL HARRINGTON: [Interjecting] That's not me! That's Mike Harrison - different person entirely. I'm Michael from the Gazette. We're actually rivals.

DI RACHEL KUMAR: My apologies. Mr. Mike Harrison then. He claims your canvassers were aggressive.

JAMES MORRISON: That's completely false. We have video evidence of him harassing our volunteers. Emma Watson took photos.

BARRY CADE: DI Kumar, we'll cooperate fully. James, get Emma's evidence to the Detective Inspector today.

ALICE CHEN: Can we discuss the business impact? My association now has 23 members, including both Patels from Newton Rd and the new Turkish restaurant on High St - Ankara Delights, owned by the Özturk family.

DR. JENNIFER HART: From a medical perspective, I've prepared a report showing that Shore Road is used by 67% of emergency vehicles reaching North Swanage. Closing it adds an average of 4.3 minutes to response times.

UNKNOWN SPEAKER 2: Hi, I'm Tom Chen - Alice's son. I'm a data analyst at Dorset Digital, and I've been analyzing the survey data. The CAPTCHA didn't just reduce responses - it specifically blocked IP addresses from the NS1 and NS2 postcodes.

PHILIPPE EDES: NS1 and NS2 - that's North Swanage. They targeted our area specifically?

TOM CHEN: Exactly. And here's the kicker - Granicus, EHQ's parent company, has a contract with DCC worth £2.3 million. That's Dorset County Council for the record.

SANDRA WILLIAMS: [Phone] I can confirm that. And there's more - Tony Powell's DCF received a grant of £85,000 from DCC just two weeks before the consultation launched.

MARGARET THORNE: This is bigger than we thought. We need to get Margaret Haywood involved - she's the new transparency officer at DCC.

MICHAEL HARRINGTON: I'll run a series on this. Front page Sunday edition. Barry, can NSTCG provide a full timeline?

BARRY CADE: James will coordinate with you, Michael. Now, about Hollister - he's already spreading rumors that Phil isn't eligible to serve because of some technicality.

PHILIPPE EDES: Let him try. My paperwork is bulletproof. More importantly, I've scheduled meetings with the Swanage Chamber of Commerce and the Purbeck Tourism Board next week.

ALICE CHEN: The Chamber president, Richard Blackstone, is sympathetic. His hotel, the Purbeck Arms, would lose 30% of guests if Shore Rd closes.

DR. HART: I should mention - Dr. Patricia Kumar at the surgery (no relation to the Detective Inspector) has been collecting patient impact statements. Over 200 so far.

DI RACHEL KUMAR: If I may return to the harassment claims - Mr. Morrison, when can you provide the counter-evidence?

JAMES MORRISON: This afternoon. We also have witness statements from Colin Fletcher and Marcus Thompson who saw Harrison's behavior.

UNKNOWN SPEAKER 1 [Revealed as DI Kumar]: Thank you. For the record, making false police reports is a serious offense.

TOM CHEN: Barry, I've created a database of all the evidence. It's hosted on secure servers at Dorset Digital. Full encryption, daily backups.

SANDRA WILLIAMS: [Phone] The County CEO, Charles Pemberton, wants to meet with NSTCG leadership. He's worried about the Statistics Authority investigation.

BARRY CADE: Tell Pemberton we're happy to meet, but only with legal representation present. Margaret, can STC provide a lawyer?

MARGARET THORNE: I'll speak to our legal counsel, Jonathan Whitmore at Whitmore & Associates.

MICHAEL HARRINGTON: One more thing - I've heard rumors that EngagementHQ is pulling out of their Dorset contract. My source at Granicus says it's damage control.

ALICE CHEN: If they pull out, doesn't that affect all council consultations?

PHILIPPE EDES: It would. Every consultation for the next two years was supposed to use their platform.

DR. HART: Speaking of consultations, the NHS is planning one about the new medical center. If EHQ pulls out, that's delayed too.

TOM CHEN: Actually, my company, Dorset Digital, could provide alternative consultation platforms. Open source, fully transparent.

BARRY CADE: Interesting. Tom, can you prepare a proposal?

UNKNOWN SPEAKER 2 [Revealed as Tom Chen]: Already working on it.

SANDRA WILLIAMS: [Phone] I have to go - Pemberton's calling an emergency meeting. Keep me posted.

[Phone disconnects]

DI RACHEL KUMAR: I have what I need. Mr. Morrison, I'll expect that evidence today. Good day everyone.

[DI Kumar leaves]

MARGARET THORNE: With the detective gone, let's be frank. Hollister and Powell won't give up. They have too much invested.

PHILIPPE EDES: Agreed. But now we have momentum, media support, and I'm inside the council. The game has changed.

ALICE CHEN: The Business Assoc is planning a rally next Saturday. High Street, 2 PM. Can we count on NSTCG support?

BARRY CADE: Absolutely. James, coordinate with Alice on logistics.

MICHAEL HARRINGTON: I'll cover the rally. Phil, can I interview you beforehand?

PHILIPPE EDES: Of course. How about Friday at 4?

DR. HART: Before we adjourn, I should mention - the Royal College of Emergency Medicine is interested in our case. Shore Road closures affecting emergency access is a national issue.

TOM CHEN: That's huge. National attention could force DCC to back down.

BARRY CADE: Excellent. Let's wrap up with clear actions. James - evidence to DI Kumar today. Tom - consultation platform proposal. Alice - rally planning. Phil - Chamber and Tourism Board meetings. Dr. Hart - liaise with Royal College. Margaret - STC legal counsel. Michael - Sunday expose. Everyone clear?

ALL: Clear.

BARRY CADE: One last thing. We've won a battle, not the war. Stay vigilant, document everything, and watch each other's backs. Meeting adjourned.

[Various goodbye exchanges as people leave]

PHILIPPE EDES: [Privately to Barry] Hollister approached me after the election results. Offered to 'guide' me on the council. I told him I had all the guidance I needed.

BARRY CADE: Good. He's trying to control you already. Stay strong, Phil. We're just getting started.

tasks.name: Meet with Chamber and Tourism Board

transgressions.summary: IP blocking targeting North Swanage postcodes
Conflict of interest - £85,000 grant before consultation

speaker_disambiguation: Unknown Speaker 1 revealed as DI Rachel Kumar
Unknown Speaker 2 revealed as Tom Chen
relationship_complexity: No relation explicitly stated (the two Kumars)
temporal_complexity: Relative time references (next week, Friday at 4)
entity_role_evolution: New roles discovered for existing people
